--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>
> Hello Ken-
=
> 
> As you know, I am interested in these issues. I would like to understa=
nd
> your suggestions below more clearly, and your intuitions for them. Ple=
ase
> see my questions below.
> 
> > I would suggest putting such informati=
on in a centered locations in their own
> > layers, or in other dimensions =
(as you suggest)
> 
> How do these two suggestions differ? When you suggest=
 'another layer' isn't
> that just shorthand for 'another dimension'? For e=
xample, the only way you
> can have two inputs with the same centering (e.g=
. X=3D0, Y=3D0) would be to have
> them have different Z dimensions, which =
to me implies another layer (in the
> geometric representation space).
> 
>=
 Can you give examples your suggestions so I can conceptualize them?
> 

Je=
ff, I didn't explain what I meant very clearly.  By another layer, I meant =
a single node that is placed at e.g. a new Z position.  By a dimension, I m=
eant a set of nodes placed at a new Z dimension.  For example, something li=
ke "health" could be a single node whose activation level represents health=
.  Or you could have five nodes that represent, "poor health," "not feeling=
 good," "medium health," etc.  So you could actually turn the data of inter=
est in to a geometric dimension in the substrate.

> More importantly, why =
do you think centering the nodes but putting them in
> different layers/dim=
ensions is the right way to go (versus just putting them
> in their own are=
a within the pre-existing dimensionality)?
> 

If you put an arbitrary node=
 in a pre-existing area, it implies that somehow the value of that node is =
related to the values of the nodes in the surrounding area.  For example, i=
f you have a bunch of knee angles in one row and then "health" in the same =
row, it implies that health should be treated somehow like a knee angle, wh=
en there is actually no clear connection between health and knee angles.  T=
he geometry is like a language for describing what is related to what.  So =
separated something unrelated into a new layer seems like a better idea.

>=
 
> >, and sticking with HyperNEAT
> > overall.  It may work well actually =
to make things like health and ammo actual
> > geometric dimensions.  Howev=
er, you could also let them be single nodes that
> > are alone in their own=
 layers, or in parts of the input layer that are
> > separated from the res=
t of it.
> > 
> 
> I have basically the same questions here, as I don't get=
 the difference
> between these suggestions.
> 

I think I meant basically =
the same thing here, except I was giving a specific example.  

ken

> Sorr=
y if I am just not thinking of something obvious.
> 
> -Jeff
> > 
> > 
> > =
--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, tansey@ wrote:
> >> 
> >> Hi Ken,
> >> 
> >> T=
hanks for the clarification.
> >> 
> >> As a follow-up, do you have any sug=
gestions on how to handle mixed geometric
> >> and
> >> non-geometric data?=

> >> 
> >> For instance, if you're evolving a bot for a FPS, you may have =
some geometric
> >> representation of the world. However, there may also be=
 other relevant
> >> information like health or ammo. It seems like there a=
re only three solutions
> >> right now:
> >> 
> >> 1. Use regular NEAT and =
lose the regularity of the world.
> >> 2. Use HyperNEAT and force the healt=
h and ammo information to be represented
> >> as
> >> extra dimensions even=
 though they can be handled by a single input node.
> >> 3. Evolve a HyperN=
EAT agent separately then use its input(s) as secondary
> >> input(s) to a =
regular NEAT controller.
> >> 
> >> Is there a fourth approach? Or is there=
 generally a preference for one of the
> >> above three approaches?
> >> 
>=
 >> Wesley
> >> 
> >> Quoting Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@>:
> >> 
> >>> Wesl=
ey, the main insight motivating r(x) is that it aligns the agent
> >>> geom=
etry
> >>> with the team geometry.  That is, the left side of the agent is =
on the same
> >>> side of the agent as the left side of the team, which is =
how it usually
> >>> would
> >>> be in the real world.  Nevertheless, you m=
ake a good point that the
> >>> substrate
> >>> could be 3D as an alternati=
ve.  There is nothing wrong with doing it that
> >>> way
> >>> and it does =
have its own advantages.  In fact, we have experimented with
> >>> both
> >=
>> approaches to laying out agents for multiagent learning (although only r=
(x)
> >>> is in the GECCO paper), and both are valid.
> >>> 
> >>> ken
> >>=
>

 substrate of more than 2

ous agent experiment. Is there
